channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Spain’s Media Industry Changes Rapidly, Some Worry About Objectivity
item.description: The news media outlets across the country are facing financial and governmental constraints, factors industry experts say could combine to hinder free expression.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Carlos Lujan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedro J. Ramírez, second from left, this week in Madrid at El Español, a news website he created after he left the top job at El Mundo.

item.title: In Pacific Trade Deal, Vietnam Agrees to U.S. Terms on Labor Rights
item.description: Terms detailed in a newly released text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership include workers’ freedom to unionize and to strike.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES
item.media:credit: Aaron Joel Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers assembling women's shoes at a factory in southern Vietnam.

item.title: Your Morning Briefing: Taiwan-China Meeting, Trans-Pacific Partnership
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA SHANNON
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster of the National League for Democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in Yangon, Myanmar. Elections are Sunday.

item.title: Bomb Is ‘Possibility’ in Loss of Russian Jet Over Egypt, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama said Thursday evening that there was “a possibility” that a terrorist bomb was responsible for the destruction of a passenger plane that broke up Saturday in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The funeral in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday of Alexei Alexeev, who died in the crash of the Russian jet.

item.title: As Refugees Flee, Thousands of Children Have No Country to Call Their Own
item.description: A United Nations report estimates that 70,000 stateless children are born annually, in regions as disparate as Southeast Asia, the Caribbean and even the heart of Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Filling a Top Post, Netanyahu Reconsiders Nominee Who Insulted Obama
item.description: The prime minister’s choice, Ran Baratz, has come under fire over Mr. Baratz’s suggestion that President Obama was anti-Semitic and that Secretary of State John Kerry had the intellect of a preteenager.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, second from right, at the weekly cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Britain, Concerned About Russian Crash, Halts Sinai Flights
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron announced the suspension of all flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Russia's Emergency Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russian emergency services personnel at the site of the Metrojet crash in the Sinai Peninsula, Egypt.

item.title: Death Toll in Pakistan Factory Collapse Rises to 20
item.description: Rescue workers stepped up efforts to find survivors a day after the collapse of a factory on the outskirts of Lahore.
item.dc:creator: WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Outrage Ripples Through Romania After Government’s Collapse
item.description: Protests demanding political change that began after a nightclub fire continued even after two officials, including the prime minister, resigned.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Bucharest, Romania, on Wednesday night, continuing protests and calling for significant changes in government.

item.title: Poll Finds Global Consensus on a Need to Tackle Climate Change
item.description: A Pew poll in 40 countries found that in all but one, a majority of respondents support limiting greenhouse gas emissions, though intensity of concern varies.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Seeks Explanation for Kunduz Hospital Attack
item.description: The group said that the hospital was clearly marked and that it still had not received an official explanation for the American strikes that killed 30 people on Oct. 3.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Christopher Stokes, the general director of Doctors Without Borders, at a news conference on Thursday in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Germany 101: Refugees Get Guidebook to Their New Home
item.description: With some 758,400 newly arrived asylum seekers, Germany faces the daunting task of trying to integrate people from vastly different cultures.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Seems to Have Myanmar’s Countryside in Her Corner
item.description: As the Burmese prepare to vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the ruling party’s efforts to win over the people appear to have come up short.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvesting rice in the village of Kwun Chan Kone, a five-hour drive from Myanmar’s largest city, Yangon. Many local farmers favor the opposition party, the National League for Democracy, led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

item.title: Scientists Study Links Between Climate Change and Extreme Weather
item.description: A collection of studies examining extreme weather in 2014, including drought, floods and storms, found signs that climate change likely played a role in about half.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ
item.media:description: A house in Pahoa, Hawaii, damaged by Hurricane Iselle in August. A new study says climate change probably had a role in the unusually high number of cyclones that hit Hawaii last year.

item.title: European Union Predicts Economic Gains From Influx of Migrants
item.description: Officials forecast that the three million arrivals expected by 2017 would provide a net gain of perhaps a quarter of 1 percent by that year to the European economy.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Vancon Laetitia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nematullah Jasor, right, an Afghan refugee who arrived in Germany in 2013, now works in the town of Passau. European officials predict that migrants will provide at least a small economic lift in the next three years.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Wrong Turn for Guatemalan Democracy
item.description: After six months of protests, the country has a new president. But is it on a path toward real reform?
item.dc:creator: ANITA ISAACS

item.title: Letter From Europe: Resistance to Authority in Greece as Pessimism Takes Hold
item.description: Greeks no longer believe, if they ever did, in the functionality of politics, the mayor of Athens said.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Yiorgos Kaminis after being re-elected mayor of Athens in 2014. “When I look at Europe, I don’t have any optimism at all,” he says.

item.title: A Brief Guide to Myanmar’s Election
item.description: What are the prospects for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and how much control does the military retain?
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of the Myanmar opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, listening during a campaign rally for the National League for Democracy in Yangon.

item.title: Villa Baviera Journal: Chilean Community, Once a Site of Torture, Reinvents Itself for Tourists
item.description: Villa Baviera, once home to a secretive German sect and the scene of torture, abuse and executions, tries to stay alive as a tourist attraction.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: What was once a communal dining hall for members of a German sect has been turned into a public restaurant in Villa Baviera, Chile.

item.title: China Moves to Crack Down on Counterfeit Disney Products
item.description: A government agency has announced a nationwide “special action” program aimed at stamping out imitation goods that infringe on the American company’s trademarks.
item.category: State Administration for Industry and Commerce (China)
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A souvenir store in Hong Kong Disneyland.
